lines.text:
[walking into the church and seeing the Electric Mayhem]
They don't look like Presbyterians to me.
Ahh, a bear in his natural habitat - a Studebaker.

[after the Electric Mayhem paint the Studebaker]
Doc Hopper will never recognize you now.
I don't know how to thank you guys.
I don't know *why* to thank you guys.
Hey, why don't you join us?
Where are you going?
We're following our dream!
Really? I have a dream, too!
Oh?
But you'll think it's stupid.
No we won't, tell us, tell us!
Well, I want to go to Bombay, India and become a movie star.
Hollywood.
Sure, if you want to do it the *easy* way.

[to Kermit]
We've picked up a weirdo...
Where did you learn to drive?
I took a correspondence course.
Hey, Fozzie, I want you to turn left if you come to a fork in the road.
Yes sir, turn left at the fork in the road.
[drives past a giant fork]
Kermit!
I don't believe that.
I like the movie fine so far.
It hasn't started yet.
That's what I like about it.
[they laugh]

[singing; repeated lines]
Someday we'll find it, the rainbow connection. The lovers, the dreamers, and me.

[singing]
Life's like a movie, write your own ending...

[singing]
Keep believing, keep pretending; we've done just what we've set out to do, thanks to the lovers, the dreamers, and you!
That's pretty dangerous building a road in the middle of the street. I mean, if frogs couldn't hop, I'd be gone with the Schwinn.
It's not often you see a guy that green have the blues that bad.
Kermit, does this film have socially redeeming value?
[first lines]
I'm Statler.
I'm Waldorf. We're here to heckle "The Muppet Movie".
Gentlemen, that's straight ahead. Private screening room D.
Private screening?
Yeah, they're afraid to show it in public.
[they laugh as their car proceeds forward]

[gushing]
Ooh, you mad, impetuous thing, it's champagne!
Not exactly. Sparkling Muscatel, one of the finest wines of Idaho.
Kermie, whisper sweet nothings into my ear.
Uh... motorcycle cop.
"Motorcycle cop" is a sweet nothing?
A motorcycle cop is chasing us.
Well, how do you like the film?
I've seen detergents leave a better film than this.
[they laugh]
It's too bad the dancing girls are on vacation; this crowd's getting ugly.
Huh. If you think this crowd's ugly, you should see the dancing girls.
I didn't promise anybody anything. What do I know about Hollywood, anyway? Just a dream I got from sitting through too many double features.
So why did you leave the swamp in the first place?
'Cause some agent fella said I had talent. He probably says that to everybody.
On the other hand, if you hadn't left the swamp, you'd be feeling pretty miserable anyhow.
Yeah. But then it would just be me feeling miserable. Now I got a lady pig, and a bear, and a chicken, a dog, a thing, whatever Gonzo is. He's a little like a turkey.

[Kermit's Conscience is sitting on a rock behind him]
Mmm - Yeah. A little like a turkey, but not much.
No I guess not. Anyhow, I brought them all out here to the middle of nowhere, and it's all my fault.
Still, whether you promised them something or not, you gotta remember - they wanted to come.
But... that's because they believed in me.
No, they believed in the dream.
Well, so do I, but...
You do?
Yeah! Of course I do.
Well then?
Well then... I guess I was wrong when I said I never promised anyone. I promised me.
You may serve us now, please.
Oh... may I?
[Professor Max Krassman has just put Kermit in the electronic beanie]

[desperate]
Please! Please! Not my frog, please!
Say goodbye to your frog, pig!
Why should I?
Because in 10 seconds, he won't know *you* from kosher bacon.

[furious]
That does it!
Gee. A Studebaker. Where did you get it?
Oh, my uncle left it to me.
Huh, is he dead?
No, he's hibernating.
'They don't look like Presbyterians to me.'"

[navigating in the Studebaker]
Bear left.
Right, frog.
Hey - frog! That's the second time! Max, I've done my best with that frog, now's the time to do my worst. Open the door.
No, YOU open the door!
What?
I'm through, Doc. The frog is right. You're asking him to do something terrible. I can't be a part of it. It's a moral decision and I'll stand by it.
I'll double your percentage.
I'll open the door.

[asks the waiter to taste the wine for him and Miss Piggy]
Will you taste it for us, please?

[tastes the wine, makes a face and spits it out]
Ooh! Ah... Excellent - choice.

[to Miss Piggy]
Should be, for ninety-five cents.

[impressed]
Ooooh!
That's toughest, meanest, *filthiest* pest hole on the face of the earth!
Why not complain to the owner?
I *am* the owner.
[when seeing Fozzie perform for the first time]
This guy's lost.
Maybe he should try Hare Krishna.
Good grief, it's a running gag.
There was this sailor who was so fat!
How fat was he?
[breaks bottle and points it towards him threateningly]

[Nervously]
Uh, he was so fat that everybody liked him and there was nothing funny about him at all.
Uncle Kermit, is this how the Muppets *really* got started?
Well, it's sort of approximately how it happened.
It is important to remember that you have to hold on to your hat.
What for?
When a German scientist tells you to hold on to your hat, it's not casual conversation. HOLD ON TO YOUR HAT! HAT! HOLD!
[Doc Hopper grabs his hat brim]
Good.
The flim is okee-dokee.
Good, roll film.
Flim is rooling!

[whispering]
This is the patriotic part.

[whispering back]
Should we stand up?
No.
[Animal roars and scares Kermit and Fozzie]
Oh, yeah, that's Animal. Show 'em what you do, Animal.
I want to - eat drums!
[chews on a cymbal]
No, no. Beat drums, beat drums!

[stops chewing]
Beat drums! Beat drums!
[Starts beating his head against that same cymbal]
Down, Animal!
DOWN!
Back!
BACK!
Sit!
SIT!
Miss Piggy, you look beautiful!
Thank you!

[aside]
Hollywood talk.
What's happening?
At the moment, *we're* what's happenin'.
Oh. Broken heart, right?

[sadly]
Does it show?
Listen, when you've been tickling the ivories as long as I have, you've seen a broken heart for every drop of rain, a shattered dream for every falling star.
Exactly. She just walked out on me.
Ah, typical. That's why I live alone.
You do, huh?
You bet. I finish work, I go home, read a book, have a couple of beers, take myself for a walk, and go to bed.
Nice and simple.
Stay away from women. That's my motto.
But I can't.
Neither can I. And that's my trouble.
Jack, get rid of this heap. Come out here!
What? What?
That's my jack.
Oh, hi Jack!
Jack not name! Jack job!

[whispering]
How many times have I told you not to talk to the customers?
Hey, Fozzie, look up ahead there.
What is that?
Maybe we should give him a ride.
I don't know, he's pretty big.

[to Big Bird]
Hey there, wanna lift?
Oh, no thanks. I'm on my way to New York City to try to break into public television.
Oh. Hm, good luck.
Oh Kermie, you were so courageous, so magnificent!
Gee, I don't know what to say.
Say the bear was magnificent. After all, I did the driving.
And I took a hundred-foot belly flop onto a moving car!
Yes, but Kermit assumed the awesome responsibility of command!
Gee.
Oh, brother.
The Electric Mayhem!
Too true. Too true. It is indeed a problem for us to 'probosculate' upon. But it seems to me the frog and the bear are temporarily out of service.
IR-RI-TA-TED! IR-RI-TA-TED!
Don't worry, Animal, your big scene is coming up.
Yeah, just be cool and eat another seat cushion.
SEAT CUSHION!
[rips off some upholstery and stuffing at the corner of his chair and eats it]
That's Piggy!
Yes, I know!
Hey, you do think we should help her with her bags?
Aah, no.
[Everyone]
No, nah, un-uh.
I'll be back later to pick up what's left of the frog.
What's left of the frog? You can have everything - excuse the brain!
[after he's thrown behind the bar, he pops up wearing a beard and dressed like the bartender]
[Yelling]
Okay everybody, drinks on the house!
Hey, drinks on the house! C'mon let's go!

[as everyone but him and Kermit vacate the place]
Yeah. Yeah. Go, go. They're on the house!
[Cut to the roof of the El Sleezo, where everyone else is now]
[Among the confusion and chatter of everyone else]
Wait a minute! There're no drinks up here! What's he talking about? The bartender told us there were drinks on the house!

[Cut back to the interior of the El Sleezo. After Fozzie removes the beard and moustache]
Works every time.
Oh, I'm so nervous. If I'm not funny, I won't be able to live with myself.
Well, then you'll have to get another apartment, won't you?

[watching Gonzo fly over the fair with a bunch of balloons]
Gonzo! What are you doing?
About seven knots!

[after singing "America the Beautiful"]
Patriotism swells in the heart of the American bear.
[the members of The Electric Mayhem are introducing themselves one by one]
I'm, uh, uhh...
Zoot. Sax is your axe. Uh-oh, Zoot skipped a groove again.
Listen, we're a small business but we've expanded. Expanded! Just like you frogs expand. Don't you frogs expand?
[puffs his cheeks]
That's a myth.
What?
Myth! Myth!
Yeth?
Huh?
[same with Fozzie]
[to Fozzie]
C'mon, bear, burn rubber!
[after Fozzie speeds off from the TV shop]
Max! Follow that frog!
[Max drives off leaving Doc Hopper behind]

[screaming]
Max!
[Max stops and reverses the car]
Follow that frog with *me* in the car!
Sound is ready. Gimme a level.

[yelling through microphone]
*TES-TIIIING!*
[we see Bunsen's headphones rattle repeatedly]
Ah-ha-ha-ha.
Hello, I'd like an ice cream.
What do you want? Chocolate, vanilla, coffee, peach, fudge, rum, banana?
Honey.
Honey? I beg your pardon, I hardly know you.
Ah! But seriously, I'd like a honey ice cream cone for me, and a dragonfly ripple for my friend the frog.
OK.
[handing him the ice creams]
One honey cone for the bear.
Yeah.
And one dragonfly ripple for the frog.
Yucha.
Don't get 'em mixed up.
Gotcha.
Kermit, where are we?

[Looking at a map]
Well, let's see. We're just traveling down this little black line here, and uh, just crossed that little red line over here.

[after taking his eyes off the road to focus on the map]
How about, let's take the blue line, huh?
No, we can't take that, that's a river.
Oh. I knew that.
Yeah sure.
Well, listen Kermit, why don't we just go and...

[Cutting him off]
Fozzie? Uh, Fozzie?
Yeah?
Who's driving?

[after Fozzie parks the car in front of a church and turns it off]
Boy, it feels like we've been driving for days.

[Still upbeat]
Funny, yet I'm still wide awake!
Yup. Me, too.
[Two seconds later Fozzie's head falls back, and he immediately starts snoring. Kermit jumps at that, then shrugs]

[quietly]
Me, too.
[Drops his head back and settles in himself]
What in the name of Fats Waller is that?
A four foot prune!

[on reading "The Muppet Movie" sceenplay]
This is a narrative of very heavy-duty proportions.
That's enough of that, Harry!

[Movie stops after burning in projector lamp]
Hey, what happened?

[In projector booth, covered in film]
Gersh gurndy morn-dee burn-dee, burn-dee, flip-flip-flip-flip-flip-flip-flip-flip-flip.

[pointing to a billboard showing a bucket of "Doc Hopper's French Fried Frog Legs"]
Isn't that splendid? Just splendid! Just take a look at it.
All I can see are millions of frogs with tiny crutches.

[to audience]
I hope you appreciate that I'm doing all my own stunts.
Crazy Harry plays with electricity! AH-HA-HA-HA-HA!
Rolling! OK everybody, stay in focus.
It's the man with the badge, the PO-lice, the cops, the fuzz, the P-I-...
Don't you dare!
I wouldn't think of it.

[to the audience]
You're not gonna believe who the winner is, folks.
Oh, come now, Charlie, it's their movie.
Oh, so it is, yes.
Misssss... Piggy!
Golden teeth and golden tones, welcome to my presence.
Hey, maybe this frog does everything. He talks, he sings, he dances, he tells jokes, he even rides a bicycle. Max, find me a frog and a bear in a tan Studebaker.

[Fozzie and Kermit appear in Fozzie's Studebaker, now rainbow-colored]
Gee, Doc, all I can see is a frog and a bear in a rainbow-colored Studebaker.

[last lines - into camera]
Go home! Go home! Bye-bye.
[faints]
Oh, waiter...

[reluctantly]
Yes? May I help you?
The uh, the wine, please.
[explaining his machine]
We take your friend, the little F-O-R-G, put him in the chair, clamp on the terminals, drop the electronic "yarmulke," and then throw what we call in German - THE SVITCH!
[laughs]
Yes, my friend, soon it'll be a hot time in the old skull tonight!
[turns off the switch]
Thank you, Herr Machine.
[putting Kermit in the machine]
Oh, will you stop whimpering? Go out like a frog, not a little toad. Okay, Herr Machine, this is big time! Ready to go to work? Hand clamps! Foot clamps!
[locks Kermit in]

Ha, ha, ha, you can struggle all you want now, frog, it'll do you very little *good*! And now, it's time to drop the electronic beanie. Soon you'll have enough voltage coursing through your little frog brain to light up Cincinatti!

[about Krassman's machine]
What does it do?
What does it do? What does it do? It turns the brains into guacamole!
[Doc Hopper is following Kermit and Fozzie in the rainbow disguised car]
Fozzie, they're right behind us!
I know, I know.
But Fozzie, how did they recognize us?
They recognized YOU. There's a hundred bears around.

[while driving down the road in the car]
Ah, a bear in his natural habitat. A Studebaker!
Yeah, the road manager. We couldn't go anywhere without him.
He's the man with the contacts?
No, he's the man with the van.

[to Miss Piggy]
If you were a chicken, you'd be impeccable.

[as he and the gang enter his office]
Um, Mr. Lord, forgive the interruption, but I'm here to audition.
Yes! Yes!
We've come over 2000 miles, and...
[Stops when Lew Lord turns around in his chair to face him, making him nervous now]
Um... oh boy.
Kermie, we are all with you.
Um, please sir, my name is Kermit the Frog, and we've read your ad, and, well, we've come to be rich and famous.

[Has a brief staredown with Kermit, then into his intercom]
Miss Tracy, prepare the standard 'Rich and Famous' contract for Kermit the Frog and Company.
[They all look stunned for a moment, then all the rest of the Muppets start cheering and celebrating behind Kermit, who just looks on shocked and starry-eyed]
What the heck's going on here? A pig that goes bananas? What is this, a luau?

[singing]
I've heard it too many times to ignore it. It's something that I'm s'posed to be.
I'm a professional. I've had three performances.
[Kermit and the Muppets arrive in Hollywood]
Oh, Kermie, look, it's wonderful. Like a dream come true.
Well, don't count your tadpoles until they've hatched, I still have to audition, you know.
Hey, there ain't nothin' to it but to do it!

[closes the door]
And where do you think you're going?
Oh, hi there. We're here to audition for Lew Lord.
You just can't walk in here off the street you know, especially with all these animals.
Animals? Wh-What's wrong with animals?
[Muppets mutter indignantly but indistinctly]
This is a movie studio, not a zoo. Besides...
[sneezes]
...I'm allergic to animal hair. Now get along all of you.

Now wait a second, miss. I may not be one of your fancy Hollywood frogs, but I deserve a chance, and we're going to stay right here in this office until you let us in to see Lew Lord. Aren't we, gang?
[the Muppets shout "Yes" indistinctly]

[on the phone]
Security, Miss Tracey. I want to report a...
[the Muppets shake their fur, causing the secretary to sneeze convulsively until she finally opens the office door]
Hello, sailor, buy me a drink?
Well, you see, I'm not a sailor, I'm a frog.
Oh, cut the small talk and buy me a drink.
I don't even know you.
Hey. Did you make a move with my girl?
No, sir.
He did too. He touched me.
Ugh. Wash up, you'll get warts.
That's a myth.
Yeah, but she's my "myth"!
No, no, myth, myth!
Yeth?
[repeated line]
No problem.

[singing]
You can't live with 'em, you can't live without 'em. / There's something irresistible-ish about 'em. / We grin and bear it 'cause the nights are long. / I hope that something better comes along.
Bernie, the agent.
Hey, listen, Bernie the Agent, why don't you say "hello" to Arnie the alligator?
[repeated line]
Wacka, wacka.

[to Crazy Harry]
You know, I hear this movie's dynamite.
[Crazy Harry blows up a chair]
Frankly, Miss Piggy, I don't give a hoot.
No frog's gonna make a monkey out of me!
If what I'm saying doesn't make any sense, well then... go ahead and kill me.

[takes off his hat and fluffs his hair; reluctantly]
All right boys. Kill him.
This is Snake Walker. Tell 'em what you do, Snake.

[removes his sunglasses]
Kill frogs.

[about the Insta-Grow pills]
What else do these pills make big?
Oh, they'll work on anything, but the effect is, sadly, temporary.
Sadly temporary.
And now, filling in for the vacationing El Sleezo Dancing Girls, the funny, furry, fabulous - Fozzie Bear!
red or green?
Can I give you a word of advice?
What?
Why not take both?
[smiles encouragingly]

[gasps]
What a wild idea!
Yeah, a beautiful chicken like that deserves two balloons.
You're right.
I have guys come in all the time. Sometimes, they'll get a buncha balloons for their girls, and they go gaga for it.
Gaga? I'll take the whole bunch!
Gaga! Gaga!
ha ha!

[trying to dash after the others, who are continuing on their way to Hollywood in Fozzie's new car]
Hey! Hey, where're you goin'? Hey! Wait for me! I wanna go to Hollywood! Hey, wait for me! C'mon, guys! Wait, please! I wanna go to Hollywood!
Miss Piggy? Miss Piggy! Are you Miss Piggy?
Yes.
Telephone.
Phone call for Kermit the Frog. You Kermit the Frog?
Yeah.
Phone.
Help! Hello! This is a serious call for help!
Uh, yeah?
Someone - help! Ah - I, oh! Oh! You, you with the banjo - uh, can you help me? I have lost my sense of direction.
Uh, have you tried Hare Krishna?

[briefly laughs sarcastically]
No. No, I mean I'm really lost.
Uh, one second.
[he tries to catch a fly with his tongue, but misses]
Uh, darn I missed. You know, that's the first thing to go on a frog, his tongue. The tongue goes and you can't catch flies.
Well, that's rough, I'm sorry about your tongue, but I have to get out of this swamp; I have to catch a plane.
With *that* tongue? No way.
[laughs]
But seriously, there's a boat dock just downstream.
Thank you.
Just watch out for the alligators.
I will.
[he starts to leave but turns back to Kermit, apprehensive]
Alligators?
That's right.
Did you say alligators?
al-lee-gay-twers.

[singing]
There's not a word yet, for old friends who've just met.

[after Kermit has turned down Doc Hopper's offer]
Five hundred dollars? Would you consider a bear in a frog suit?
Fozzie!
I'm sorry, sir, I just lost my head.

[as Kermit and Fozzie drive off]
Just a minute, Mr. Frog. Everything's negotiable!
It's the fuzz, the police, the man with the badge. The P - I...
Don't you dare!
Oh, I wouldn't think of it.
Did we do something wrong, Officer?
[Shocked when it reveals that the police officer is Max]
Okay, Guys! Let him explain the violation issue.
This whole disguise is only so that I can warn you!
Okay, Sure, Sure.
I never thought Doc was going to hurt Kermit, I thought he was going to lean on him. But now he has hired a frog killer in from the coast, And the man is DEADLY!
[Everybody gets shocked about the frog killer]
Hey Dr. Teeth, What's up ahead?
Well, Just an old ghost town.
Okay.
[to Max]
You tell Doc Hopper. I'll wait for him there.
What?

[as everybody get scared and concerned]
You could killed, Kermit.
Listen you guys, I can't spend my whole life running away from bullies, It's time for a showdown.
